text:
Multilingual content is a tremendous challenge. After many years of trying and testing many different approaches and strategies, I’ve come to the conclusion that there isn’t an ideal setup unless you have the resources to have a dedicated team for each language and a fully localized website, email workflows, etc. It’s a pain because every time you add a new language, you’re effectively doubling your content production if you want to offer a fully localized experience to the customer.

That’s a rabbit hole for many companies. My recommendation would be to be very rigorous about what gets translated. Can your customers get by with content in English, particularly, middle and bottom of the funnel content? I’d argue that in the B2B space, translations aren’t that critical for many types of content. Of course, that still leaves you with the problem of having to rank in local languages. At Vainu, we shifted from wanting to translate nearly everything to focus our translated efforts only on search content. This shift didn’t have a negative impact on how our customers consume content in English—most of them don’t care, but really helped us streamline content production. As for where the content lives, we have separate blogs/websites for English and each of the local languages. We don’t mix languages. That’s the worse solution, in my opinion.

in any case, this whole issue is a real head-scratcher. I’m happy to discuss about it, so don’t hesitate to message me if you have any questions.

text:
hey <@UPL0XUAG3>, I work for a language-learning app – multilingual content is part of the deal here, couldn't escape it!

Our blog and main website work the same way. They both house all content under one domain, but use a different subdirectory for each of our interface languages.

If you're looking to expand to French and German, would advise making sure that your in-house resources can commit to producing a steady stream of content for at least a 6-month period or so. That should help you build authority!

Hope that helps!

If you're looking to expand to French and German, would advise making sure that your in-house resources can commit to producing a steady stream of content for at least a 6-month period or so. That should help you build authority!

Hope that helps!

text:
Assuming you're looking for quiz-based "plan/product configutation" or product finder types of ecommerce examples:

• <https://remrise.com>
• <http://noom.com|noom.com> (this thing takes like 15 minutes and has 1-2 dark patterns hiding in it)
Any personally fitted fashion stuff like men's suits, swimwear, and bras are often quiz based. "what fit do you prefer?" and stuff like that.

Mattress/sleep products - "do you prefer firm/soft mattress".

Also check out the 'examples'/'inspiration' section on quiz widget providers such as <https://www.pickzen.com/> - they basically list out examples there.

--

For non-ecommerce examples, LeadershipIQ does a great job with B2B quizzes like "what's your leadership style" - they have a bunch of them at <https://www.leadershipiq.com/blogs/leadershipiq/tagged/quizzes>

text:
The Hellobar style that adds a ~20px bar to the top of the page isn't as intrusive as the usual popup and has been highly effective at companies I've worked for/with.

The caveat is it's full CTA and doesn't have the field. So, assuming that's a deal breaker, I concur with <@U01KH3P18RZ> on basing it on behavior signals.

All of that said, like you already mentioned, the idea of a popup is distasteful but they work too damn well. So even if you cringe at it popping up the moment they go to exit the page, if your newsletter signups are going up and to the right (and unsubscribes/churn aren't growing at the same rate) then... you already know the answer.

text: Agreed with Ronnie. I’ll just add that there’s always the option of having a _kind_ opt-in popup. In that case, you might sacrifice some points on the conversion rate to have a nice/friendly/not hostile design. There are levers you can move to both have growth _and_ avoid that distaste.

text: Unbounce lets you do this, if you have access. They are called "convertables" (and they have popups and sticky bars) and give a few options for how they fire off. Also, I've been looking into a Wordpress plugin called Boxzilla that lets you do this. <@UJ2MQ8SRH> has one on the Datablox blog I like that slides in from the side to ask you to subscribe to the blog! John, do you mind sharing what you use for that?

text: Hey there, does anyone have any recommended tools they use for A/B testing feature images on individual blog posts? We've been using Thrive Headline Optimizer on a client site for hed variants, but would love to do something similar for feature images and I can’t seem to find consistent info on the best tools available.
